bestBHT.bht: Barnabas, the son of exhortation, was filled with gladness when he witnessed the grace of God in the new converts. He urged them to have a purposeful and steadfast commitment to the faith, setting their hearts on the object of their attainment. In the midst of a pagan city like Antioch, he emphasized the need for perseverance, consistency, and progress. This revival brought joy to believers and Barnabas gave all glory to God, exemplifying a true Christian heart.

Henry Alford: 23. exhorted them all] in accordance with his name, which (iv. 36) was interpreted son of exhortation.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: when he . . . had seen the grace of God—in the new converts.
was glad—owned and rejoiced in it at once as divine, though they were uncircumcised.
exhorted them all that with purpose of heart—as opposed to a hasty and fickle discipleship.
Albert Barnes: The effect of a revival is to produce joy in the hearts of all those who love the Saviour.

A purpose... is especially a resolution of the mind in regard to future conduct, and the doctrine of Barnabas here was, undoubtedly, that it should be a regular, fixed, determined plan or design in their minds that they would henceforward adhere to God.
Such a plan should be formed by all Christians in the beginning of their Christian life, and without such a plan there can be no evidence of piety.
Marvin Vincent: Purpose [προθεσει]. Originally, placing in public; setting before.
Hence of the shew - bread, the loaves set forth before the Lord.
Something set before one as an object of attainment: a purpose.
John Calvin: When he had seen the grace of God...we gather that they were well taught."
The faithful servants of Christ must rejoice...when they see the gospel increase.
We must note Barnabas' exhortation...lest doctrine fall away, it is most requisite that it be thoroughly imprinted in the minds of the faithful by continual exhortations.
Philip Schaff: We see in this rejoicing, and in his attributing all this blessing to the free goodness of God, the marks of a true Christian heart.
Barnabas was clearly the right man to have sent to Antioch; and all generations of Christians since have had in his mission grounds for praise and for ‘glorifying God in him.’
His exhortation was simply to perseverance, heartiness, consistency, and progress.
Archibald T. Robertson: The grace of God, was glad."
A smaller man would have raised difficulties.
Persistence was needed in such a pagan city.
John Gill: The many instances of the powerful and efficacious grace of God in regeneration and conversion.
Rejoiced at heart, and gave glory to God, as every good man will, at the success of the gospel in the conversion of sinners.

With a fixed resolution in the grace and strength of Christ, they would hold to his person, exercising grace upon him, abide by his truths and ordinances, keep close to his people, adhere to his cause and interest, and hold on and out unto the end.

bhtAttempts.bht: Barnabas, known as the son of exhortation, rejoiced when he witnessed the grace of God in the new converts. His exhortation to them was to have a purposeful and steadfast commitment to the Gospel. He urged them to set their hearts on the object of their faith and to persevere in their discipleship, especially in a pagan city like Antioch. This revival brought joy to believers who recognized God's work. Barnabas' joy and attributing the blessing to God's goodness revealed his genuine Christian heart. His exhortation emphasized consistency, progression, and wholehearted dedication. The faithful believers at Antioch were thoroughly taught and encouraged to continually cling to the transformative power of God's grace, firmly resolved to hold onto Christ and His truth until the end.

Barnabas, the son of exhortation, was filled with gladness when he witnessed the grace of God in the new converts. He urged them to have a purposeful and steadfast commitment to the faith, setting their hearts on the object of their attainment. In the midst of a pagan city like Antioch, he emphasized the need for perseverance, consistency, and progress. This revival brought joy to believers and Barnabas gave all glory to God, exemplifying a true Christian heart.

Barnabas, the son of exhortation, rejoiced when he saw the grace of God in the new converts. He exhorted them to have a purpose of heart, not being hasty or fickle in their discipleship. Barnabas called them to set their hearts on their object of attainment and persistently hold on to it. In a city like Antioch, steadfastness was crucial. This revival brought joy to believers, who attributed the blessings to God's goodness. Barnabas' exhortation emphasized perseverance, consistency, and progress in their faith journey.

Barnabas, known as the son of exhortation, rejoiced when he saw the grace of God in the new converts. He exhorted them to have a purpose of heart, to not be hasty or fickle in their discipleship. Barnabas encouraged them to set their hearts on their object of attainment and persistently hold on to it. In a pagan city like Antioch, perseverance was necessary. This revival brought joy to believers, who attributed the blessings to God's goodness. Barnabas emphasized consistency, progress, and wholehearted dedication.

Barnabas, who was called the son of exhortation, was glad when he witnessed the grace of God in the newly converted believers. He urged them with purpose of heart, encouraging them to be steadfast and not hasty or fickle in their discipleship. Barnabas emphasized setting their hearts on their object of attainment and persisting in their faith. In the pagan city of Antioch, perseverance was vital. This revival brought joy to believers, acknowledging God's goodness. Barnabas's exhortation focused on consistency, progress, and wholehearted commitment.
